titlestmt.titleproper: William Helfand collection of medical ephemera
titlestmt.author: Toby A. Appel

publicationstmt.publisher: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 1, 2019 at 03:00

did.unittitle: William Helfand collection of medical ephemera

repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

did.physdesc: (16 three-ring albums and 2 archives boxes one of which is legal size)

langmaterial.language: Mostly in English, but also in a variety of other languages, among them French, German, Spanish, Italian, Swedish, Danish, and Norwegian.

did.abstract: The collection contains printed ephemera related to medicine and pharmacy either arranged in albums by William Helfand or donated in loose form. These include trade cards (some on marijuana and street drugs), postcards, advertisements in various formats for patent medicines and devices, advertisements for cancer cures, playing cards, cards of famous scientists and physicians, stock certificates for pharmaceutical companies, photographs of old pharmacies, pharmacy prescription envelopes, stereoscopic photographs, and more.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

did.unittitle: Albums

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The albums are three ring binders with medical ephemera arranged in partitioned plastic pages by William Helfand. The order within each notebook has been retained. The numbering of the notebooks has been changed by the archivist.

did.unittitle: Album 1: Trading Cards on "drug wars," AIDS, and marijuana; playing cards on medical themes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cards are in plastic sleeves, six to a page. Formerly notebook 119.

did.unittitle: "Drug Wars Trading Cards"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 37 cards, satirizing people and events. Text by Paul Brancato and Bob Callahan, art by Salim Yaqub. Published by Eclipse Enterprises, Forestville, California, copyright 1991.

did.unittitle: "AIDS Awareness: People With AIDS" trading cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 72 cards and 3 stickers. Cards depict people with AIDS, AIDS activists, groups supporting AIDS awareness, and information about AIDS. Text by William Livingstone, art by Charles Hiscock, published by Eclipse Enterprises, Forestville, California, copyright 1993.

did.unittitle: "Marijuana Stories" trading cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 109 cards with photographs and descriptions of the different varieties of hemp around the world. Various photographers. Published by InLine, Chestnut Publications, copyright 1996.

did.unittitle: Playing cards on medical themes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes various sets of playing cards: a set featuring classic travel and advertising posters; miscellaneous cards advertising drug stores or medicines; set titled, "Pioneers in Medicine Card Game" by U.S. Games Systems, Inc, Stamford Connecticut, copyright 1991; German cards on great doctors by Fevarin; set of cards on first aid by the National Safety Council, Chicago, Illinois, copyright 1981; set of medical joke cards from the 1950s or 1960s; a French set on anti-smoking by the Association Regionale de Cardiologie; "Le Jeu des Medecins Midi-Pyrenees," by Pinozac published by Baptiste Paul Grimaud, Paris; set on AIDS by the State of Florida Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services; sets of cards titled "Death on Drugs Playing Cards" and "Death Cigarette Playing Cards," both featuring skeletons, by Death Playing Cards, Alamo, California.

did.unittitle: Album 2: Advertisements for cancer "cures" and trusses

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Broadsides, advertising letters, and brochures promoting "cures" for cancer without surgery, and trusses for ruptures. Most are American. There are a few later items including one pamphlet by the American Cancer Society. On appliances for ruptures, see also Box 2, Folders 3-8.

did.unittitle: Album 3: "Ephemera Savants" -- trading cards and other pieces, chiefly showing prominent physicians and scientists

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series of illustrated cards featuring mainly famous Historical physicians and scientists.

did.unittitle: Cards featuring famous scientists and physicians

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series of cards featuring scientists and physicians distributed by: various chocolate makers, the French publishing house Fernand Nathan, Liebig's Extract of Meat (many cards chiefly French and Italian), Maltine, the Arlington Chemical Company (Liquid Peptinoids); and European cigarette companies. The same publishing company created cards for several chocolatiers. One set of cards for a chocolate maker contained first aid instructions on the back. Of note are a series of bookmarks published by Wallace Laboratories, New Brunswick, N.J., makers of the anti-anxiety drug Miltown.

did.unittitle: Stamps, both postal and non-postal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Set of stamps issued by the Chicago Heart Association in 1952; stamps by Maltzym, a drug company; a series on "Breakthroughs in Modern Medicine issued by Bhutan," and various other stamps.

did.unittitle: Set of history of medicine cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published by Panarizon Publishing Corp in 1979-1980, the 42 large-format cards cover ancient false teeth to heart transplants. Includes patent medicines and medicine shows, Margaret Sanger, nursing homes, and various episodes in public health.

did.unittitle: Album 4: Postcards and cards on medical subjects

odd.head: General
odd.p: Some items were removed before the library received the album.

did.unittitle: Postcards, mostly humorous

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes postcards advertising products, photographs of pharmacies, cartoons about the advent of National Health Insurance in Great Britain, American political satire, and others. In English, French, German, and Spanish.

did.unittitle: Cards on doctors, nurses, and chemists and their families

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: For example, there are cards for Mr. Drug the Doctor, Mrs. Drug the Doctor's Wife, Miss Drug the Doctor's Daughter, and Master Drug the Doctor's Son. These cards could be used in a game, but they are not standard playing cards. They are mostly British. Some cards have been removed from the album before its donation. Of interest is a card filed along with the doctor families for a Jewish mohel in Portland, Maine, who claims to be an "Antiseptic Specialist."

did.unittitle: Cards on healing saints, especially Cosmos and Damian
Cards on recreational drugs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One set of 36 cards, titled "Dope Fiends," features artistic covers from 1940s-1960s novels about drugs (for example, Black Opium . The descriptions provide the name of the artist and information about the book. Another set published by the Las Vegas Township Constable's Office, comes with directions for a game, "Kid's War Against Drugs"

did.unittitle: Small cards on bandaging and first aid

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some are issued by British cigarette brands such as Mitchell's Cigarettes and Wills's Cigarettes.

did.unittitle: Plastic telephone cards advertising medicines, etc.
Album 5: Admission tickets, Invitations, programs, and announcement cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume is very miscellaneous. Some material was removed from this album prior to its donation.

did.unittitle: Admission tickets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These include admission as a patient to a hospital or clinic, invitations to various medical-related events such as an excursion to visit Bellevue Hospital in England, and invitations to attend lectures, meetings, and ceremonies of medical societies and schools.

did.unittitle: Invitations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Invitations to commemorative events, lectures, exhibits, meetings, and dinners. Some are addressed to William Helfand.

did.unittitle: Programs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Programs for meetings of societies, dedications, dinners, and other special events. See also dinner program in honor of Robert Koch in Box 2, Folder 1.

did.unittitle: Announcements and advertisements

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most are postcard size and advertise healers, products, and book dealers.

did.unittitle: Album 6: Treatments for asthma, hay fever, and other bronchial complaints; remedies for deafness
Advertisements for physicians and remedies for asthma, hay fever, and other bronchial complaints

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Advertisements in a variety of formats; letters, postcards, pamphlets, broadsides, clippings from magazines, stamps, and matchbook covers. Most are American and British and represent a variety of products. There are several questionnaires for patients to fill out before they are treated. A few of the companies are P. Harold Hayes, Buffalo, N.Y., who published The Hayes Bulletin; Frontier Asthma Company, Buffalo, N.Y.; The Blosser Company, Atlanta, Georgia; and the Carbolic Smoke Ball, London. Of note are a series of modern postcards for the National Asthma Campaign, UK, and by 3M Pharma for a French congress in pneumology in 1997.

did.unittitle: Advertisements for remedies for deafness

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included, among other companies, are several advertisements for George P. Way, Detroit, Michigan; and for the Mears Ear Phone Co., New York. There is an older advertisement for Dr. McNair's Acoustic Oil. See also Box 1, folder 21.

did.unittitle: Album 7: Advertisements for electric belts other electro-medical apparatus

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Advertisements for electromagnetic appliances for medical use. The majority are for Harness' Electropathic Belt and Harness' Electric Corset; and the Medical Battery Co., Ltd., London, to be obtained at the Electropathic & Zander Institute. Among other advertisers of electromedical products in Britain, France, and America are Dr. Alfred Sanden, New York ; Dr. Scott's Electric Flesh Brush, New York; Thomas E. Hooker galvanic apparatus, Wellington, Somerset: the Magneto-Electric Battery Co., London; Dr. Carter Moffat's Electric Body Belt; the VEEDEE for Vibratory Massage, London; Pulvermacher's Ltd., London; Dr. U. L. Girard, Paris; Jerome Kidder's Electro-Medical Apparatus; Dr. Lowder's Magneto-Electric Battery, London; Dr. B.-T. MacLaughlin, Paris; Darlow & Co., London. The volume also includes a British patent for the manufacture of plasters for medical purposes.

did.unittitle: Album 8: Advertisements for Beecham's Pills, Elliman's Embrocation, and Eno's 'Fruit Salt'

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Advertisements in this album have come mostly from magazines. Beechams Pills, St. Helen's, Lancashire, England, England, was a cure-all especially for "bilious and nervous disorders." Items include a few games or amusements, as for example, "Beecham's Rosette Puzzle." There is also a receipt for the purchase of Beecham's Pills by a drug store in 1908. One racist advertisement features a black maid with the caption "What am good for the Missus am good for me."

Elliman's Universal Embrocation or Elliman's Royal Embrocation were manufactured by Elliman and Sons & Co., Slough, England. The ads, including seven postcards, featured sports and especially horses and riding. Elliman's Universal Embrocation was said to provide relief from rheumatism and other aches and pains. Elliman's Royal Embrocation was used "for Horses, Cattle, and Dogs."
Eno's 'Fruit Salt,' "the World-Famous Effervescent Saline," was prepared by J.C. Eno, Ltd, in London. It was said to purify the blood and cure stomach ailments as well as a variety of other ills.

did.unittitle: Album 9: Medical politics; radio talks on history of medicine; miscellany
Pamphlets and advertisements against the Wagner-Murray-Dingell Bills

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pamphlets, several including cartoons, by organized medicine and dentistry against President Truman's national health care plan. The plan is portrayed as "socialized medicine," "political medicine," and "strictly un-American."

did.unittitle: Other medical politics

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Program of the First Annual Convention of the United Medicine Manufacturers of America, intended "to formulate ways and means to protect the Ready Packaged Medicine Industry," no date; two pamphlets of the National League for Medical Freedom opposing "medical monopoly," 1911 and no date; pamphlet titled "The Inoculation Maniac," ca. 1916, by the California Anti-Vivisection Society, ca. 1915; cartoon on "The War on Quackery"; broadside "Médecins Français!" calling upon physicians to aid the Comité National des Médecins Français to combat insurrection in Algeria, no date.

did.unittitle: Radio talks on "Devils, Drugs and Doctors," by Howard W. Haggard, Yale University

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These radio talks were broadcast over CBS in 1931 and sponsored by Eastman Kodak Company. The six pamphlets provide the text of the talks. Haggard was then associate professor of physiology at Yale, and an avid historian of medicine. He was the author of Devils, drugs, and doctors: the story of the science of healing from medicine-man to doctor (New York: Harper and Brothers, 1929).

did.unittitle: Miscellany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two small broadsides related to a meeting of the subscribers of the Bridgnorth Dispensary after the resignation of Mr. Lampet, one of the surgeons at the dispensary, 1817.

did.unittitle: Album 10: Commemorative postal stamps, stock certificates; redeemable coupons; and U.S. forms for the use of opium and alcohol in medicine
Commemorative postage stamps

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stamps commemorating health-related people and subjects. Most are U.S. They include official "First Day of Issue" pages on commemoratives issued by the U.S. Postal Service as well as full sheets of stamps. Among the persons are Harvey W. Wiley, Harvey Cushing, Joseph Priestley, Charles Drew, and George Papanicolaou. Among subjects are pharmacy, chemistry, osteopathic medicine, health research, and alcoholism.

did.unittitle: Stock certificates related to pharmacy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These include shares in drug stores and drug companies, several state certificates registering pharmacies, and one certificate stating that a student had attended lectures at University College, Nottingham. See Box 1, Folders 1-4 for more stock certificates.

did.unittitle: Coupons issued by apothecaries, spas, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Coupons are small (ca. 6x9 cm.), mostly German, attractively designed, and dating from the mid-nineteenth to early twentieth century. Each has a monetary unit in pfennigs or marks. Among the coupons is a one dollar "bond" for the Missionary Medical College for Women in Vellore, India.

did.unittitle: Official U.S. forms for drug stores' obtaining opium, or for use by physicians prescribing alcohol during Prohibition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Permission and tax forms for importing and dispensing opium and opium products, according to a law of 1914. Also in this volume are filled examples of "Prescription Blank - National Prohibition Act." Under Prohibition, physicians were required to fill out a form every time they prescribed alcohol as a medication.

did.unittitle: Album 11: Images and slides on the "medicine show"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes copies of photographs of medicine show scenes from the 19th and early 20th centuries, copies of advertisements for Indian-themed products, images and ephemera related to modern re-creations of medicine shows, and correspondence of William H. Helfand on the medicine show exhibit at the Medical Historical Library, Yale, in 1984. There is material in the album on the Kickapoo Indian Medicine Co. (New Haven) and the Oregon Indian Medicine Co. among others. Of note are copies of forms for renting halls or lots for a medicine show to visit a town. Formerly Vol. 89

did.unittitle: Album 12: Prescription envelopes (Receptkuverter) from Swedish and other Nordic pharmacies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small envelopes, about 8x12 cm., for the return of prescriptions, given by pharmacies to customers. The entire front cover was illustrated, often by an image of the pharmacy, but sometimes by artistic designs. Most of the envelopes in the album are from Sweden but a number are from other Nordic counties (Norway, Denmark, Finland, Iceland). The most recent envelopes are from the 1980s and 1990s.

did.unittitle: Album 13: Nordic prescription envelopes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Approximate size of covers is 8x12 cm.

did.unittitle: Album 14: Nordic prescription envelopes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Swedish and other Nordic apothecary envelopes with attractive designs to hold customer prescriptions after they were filled. Some feature cartoon jokes involving a customer and a pharmacist.

did.unittitle: Album 15: Prescription envelopes and envelopes for patent medicine samples, United States, Great Britain, and other countries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The British prescription envelopes typically have the patient's name written on the envelope. The envelopes that advertise a product, and once contained a product sample, are mostly American. Among these are headache cures, corn removers, and court plasters. One envelope contains a personal folding cup from the Sanitary Drinking Cup Co., Chicago. In the United Sates, pharmacists retained the prescriptions they filled.

did.unittitle: Album 16: Miscellany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Engraving of Dr. Samuel B. Collins, advertisements for his "opium antidote" and other ephemera; portrait photograph of Saide B. Collins; more prescription envelopes; more bookplates; match covers; French cards of famous scientists published by Fernand Nathan; and other advertisements.

did.unittitle: Loose material in boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These materials were donated in folders or in loose form and arranged by the archivist.

did.unittitle: Box 1: Stock certificates for drug companies; photographs of pharmacies and pharmacy schools; miscellany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This loose material has been arranged by the archivist.

did.unittitle: Stock certificates for drug companies, A-D

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Stock certificates for drug or drugstore companies, for example, Rexall. Includes many more obscure companies. Arranged by company name.

did.unittitle: Stock certificates for drug companies, E-J
Stock certificates for drug companies, K-P
Stock certificates for drug companies, Q-Z
Photographs of pharmacies (large size sleeves)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are posed professional photographs of the exterior or interior of American pharmacies. Usually the photographs include the proprietor and sometimes staff and customers. Most photographs are contemporary and usually the store is identified.

did.unittitle: Photographs of pharmacies (medium size)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a British and a French pharmacy. Some of these photographs are not identified.

did.unittitle: Photographs of pharmacies (small size)
Photographs: Brooklyn College of Pharmacy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The 1893 photograph is of a class visit to the Seabury Pharmaceutical Laboratory. Students and instructors are seated on benches. There are four women and one African-American among them. The 1920s photos show a sports team, a laboratory, pharmaceutical preparations, and a lecture hall.

did.unittitle: Photographs: Other pharmacy schools

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Faculty of Columbia College of Pharmacy, 1889; band "Pharmaceutican" from the pharmacy school at University of Nebraska, 1928. The latter includes an African American member.

did.unittitle: Photographs: Advertising of products

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One photo shows a window advertisement for "Celery King"; another shows an advertisement painted on a barn for Dr. Pierce, Buffalo, "Cures Weak Women"; and a third shows a man, posed with one foot on a box from Keystone Drug Co., South Boston, holding up a bottle of medicine.

did.unittitle: Photographs: Miscellaneous medicine (small size)
Stereoscopic views: Pharmacy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Incudes T.H. Eaton Drug Co., Toronto. Most of the stereoscopic views were intended to entertain a general audience, rather than promote a specific pharmacy. Several of the views are intended to be humorous.

did.unittitle: Stereoscopic views: Medicine
Stereoscopic views: Dentistry
Stereoscopic views: World War I
Prohibition era carton for Gibson's Pure Rye Whiskey "For Medical Purposes Only"
Carton for Chief Two Moon Bitter Oil Laxative, Waterbury, Conn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manufactured by Chief Two Moon Herb Co., Waterbury, Conn.

did.unittitle: Cardboard advertisement for Pilules Vegetales Morison, D'Arthaud-Moulin
Lactopeptine Calendar

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Calendar is "Compliments of Lactopeptine, New York Pharmacal Association, Yonkers, N.Y." It begins in October 1902 and ends September 1903. Each month features a famous historical physician.

did.unittitle: F. L. Durkee, Avon, New York, Foot and arch correction

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Broadside. "Continuing the so-called Dr. Locke method of foot and arch correction."

did.unittitle: Advertisements on remedies for hearing loss

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Broadsides and pamphlets by Gem Ear-Phone Co., George P. Way, the Mega Ear Phone, and George E. Coutant, M.D.

did.unittitle: Eckman Manufacturing Co., Philadelphia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Remedies for tuberculosis, bronchitis, and other ailments of the lungs.

did.unittitle: Dr. Hart's Vegetable Extract

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This eight-page brochure contains testimonials, the latest of which was dated 1853. The Vegetable-Extract was intended for "Epilepsy, or Falling Sickness" and also spasms, convulsions, and hysteria. S. M. Hart, M.D. lived in New York.

did.unittitle: "Highgate Dispensary" - brochure promoting vaccination

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains information on the organization of the dispensary, patients admitted, and subscribers.

did.unittitle: Constable of Bangor Borough, Report to the Judges of Northampton County on inspection of vendors of liquors

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed form filled out by David Parsons, Constable, listing the licensed places for vending liquors. Bangor Borough is in Pennsylvania.

did.unittitle: Tome V. -- Armes et Services Divers. Chapitre XXV. Le Service de Sante

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collectors' issue of postcards illustrating the costumes of health officers in the Napoleonic era.

did.unittitle: Box 2: Additional loose ephemera
Program for a dinner in honor of Robert Koch, New York
"Know Yourself," phrenology examination of a child by J. Boyd

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed one-page form with the printed date 1843. The name of the client and numbers are written in ink for the various "affective facultie" and "intellectual faculties."

did.unittitle: Rupture appliances: Brooks Rupture Appliance Co., Marshall, Mich.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two pamphlets and a "Trial Order Form." The pamphlets are titled Brooks' Rupture Appliance Greatest Discovery & Invention of the Twentieth Century . One is dated 1940; the other appears to be earlier.

did.unittitle: Rupture appliances: Brooks Appliance Co., Ltd., London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This the London Branch of Brooks Appliance Co., Marshall, Mich. The folder contains a full-page advertisement from The Humorist , June 2, 1923.

did.unittitle: Rupture appliances; Chas. Cluthe and Sons, Bloomfield, N.J.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 5 pamphlets, a guarantee certificate to furnish a truss on a 60 day trial, a standard letter in which the recipient's name is typed in, dated 1913; a form for a customer to describe his case; and a return envelope.

did.unittitle: Rupture appliances: Capt. W. A. Collings, Watertown, N.Y.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 5 small pamphlets, a large leaflet, and an envelope addressed in ink to Capt. W.A. Collings, Inc.

did.unittitle: Rupture appliances: Dr. W. S. Rice, Adams, N.Y.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 7 items.

did.unittitle: Rupture appliances: Other companies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 3 items: F. J. Stuart, More Proof that Stuart's Adhesive Plaster-Pads Cure Rupture (St. Louis, Mo., 1907); Surehold Company, Westbrook, Maine, Rupture; and Empire Manufacturing Co., Lockport, N.Y.

did.unittitle: Advertisements for treatment of asthma, hay-fever, catarrh, and consumption

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five pamphlets by Frontier Asthma Company, Buffalo, N.Y.; Dr. Blosser, Ltd, London; Dr. F. G. Kinsman, Augusta, Maine; Dr. W. G. Tucker, Mt. Gilead, Ohio (Dr, Nathan Tucker Asthma Specific; and Koch Lung Cure (Koch Inhalations), Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: Advertisement for Dr. J. D. Albright, "Specialist," Philadelphia, Rectal Diseases

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Title is Rectal Diseases: Their Treatment and Cure Without Operation , "1921 Edition." Contains patient testimonies.

did.unittitle: Power & Weightman, Philadelphia, Advertisement for Sulphate of Chinchonia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Daniel B. Smith, On the Cheaper Alkaloids of the Cinchonas , written at the request of Powers & Weightman. Smith had been President of the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy.

did.unittitle: Franklin Ford, Jackson, Michigan, remedies for men

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two broadsides and a printed letter for remedies for men by Franklin Ford, Jackson, Michigan. These include "Strong Proof that Vitala Cures Men of all Ages."

did.unittitle: Political pamphlets using medical imagery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Curry," "L'Homme au cigare entre les dents," against the Marshall Plan" (1950); and "Cures for What Ails America, Dr. B.M. Goldwater's All Purpose Defoliation Tonic" (1964).

did.unittitle: Medical and dental humor

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 3 items: Scartoons / "by a Bona fide Member of the Mystic Order of the Itching Stitch" (Boston: Rust Craft Publishers, 1955); Le Bon Dentiste (Maison M. Brodard, Montpelier); Le Charlatan: Conte humoristique , sold by Louis Conard, Paris.

did.unittitle: Issue of La Guerre Anti-Tuberculeuse

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Popular journal edited by Dr. Victor Simon, Paris. The magazine was the organ of La Ligue Internationale Contre La Tuberculose.

did.unittitle: William H. Helfand correspondence on the "medicine show"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder contains information about re-creations of medicine shows, especially correspondence of William Helfand on the Medicine Show exhibition at the American Place Theatre, 1983, for which Helfand lent materials. There is also correspondence on Helfand's talks and publications on the medicine show. This material was formerly inserted loose in Album 11.

did.unittitle: Additional materials on the "medicine show"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Additional images and newspaper articles on modern recreations of medicine shows. This material had been inserted loosely in Album 11.

did.unittitle: Secondary sources on prescription envelopes (Receptkuverter)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a letter on prescription envelopes from Hans Otto Loldrup, Dansk Farmaceutforening, to Helfand, October 30, 1979. See Albums 12-15.

did.unittitle: Sergio Rocchietta, typescript, "Physicians and Apothecaries in Moliere, in Music," no date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Found loose in one of the albums.
